<ce:figure id="fig4">
<ce:label>Scheme 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuL<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was successfully synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a one-dimensional infinite chain polymer, while the magnetic investigations demonstrate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits intrachain Cu(II)–Cu(II) antiferromagnetic interaction with <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−2.276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuLRRCl2) n  (LRR =(-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine) (1) was successfully synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. The structure of 1 is a one-dimensional infinite chain polymer, while the magnetic investigations demonstrate that 1 exhibits intrachain Cu(II)-Cu(II) antiferromagnetic interaction with J =-2.276cm-1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Using chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine, a 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuL<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was synthesized in methanol and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. X-ray analysis shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic> of orthorhombic. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a neutral, one-dimensional infinite chain polymer. The magnetic investigations demonstrate that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits intrachain Cu(II)–Cu(II) antiferromagnetic coupling with <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−2.276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Using chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors LRR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine, a 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuLRRCl2) n  (1) was synthesized in methanol and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in space group Pbca of orthorhombic. The structure of 1 is a neutral, one-dimensional infinite chain polymer. The magnetic investigations demonstrate that complex 1 exhibits intrachain Cu(II)-Cu(II) antiferromagnetic coupling with J =-2.276cm-1.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the field of coordination chemistry, it is well known that the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-bidentate ligands, such as 2,2′-bipyridine, 1,10-phenanthroline and their derivatives are versatile ligands owing to the stable coordination configuration that the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donors chelate various transition metal ions. Subsequently, the resultant complexes possess a wide rang of chemical and/or physical properties, such as catalytic, magnetic, photophysical, biochemical, electrochemical properties and assembly of supramolecular structure .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the field of coordination chemistry, it is well known that the N,N-bidentate ligands, such as 2,2'-bipyridine, 1,10-phenanthroline and their derivatives are versatile ligands owing to the stable coordination configuration that the N-donors chelate various transition metal ions. Subsequently, the resultant complexes possess a wide rang of chemical and/or physical properties, such as catalytic, magnetic, photophysical, biochemical, electrochemical properties and assembly of supramolecular structure .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">During past decades, the complexes of the type [CuLX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bidentate ligands containing <ce:italic>N</ce:italic> atoms, X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl or Br) have drawn considerable attention, because of the variable polyhedron for Cu(II) ions and the possibility of magnetic coupling interaction . In these complexes, the center Cu(II) ions can display multifarious geometries: tetrahedron or square-planar (coordination numbers of 4), trigonal bipyramidal or square-pyramidal (coordination numbers of 5) and distorted octahedral (coordination numbers of 6) . The halogen anions play two roles of terminal and bridging ligand. They are situated on axial and/or equatorial position and link the moieties [CuLX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] into dimers or chains. However, up to now, most researches are focus on dimeric Cu(II) complexes . The investigations on the structure and magnetic properties of Chloro-bridged Cu(II) chain complexes are rarely reported . Based on our recent studies , using chiral L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>) as bidentate ligand to coordinate to Cu(II) ion, we successfully prepared a 1D chain Cu(II) complex with the single-μ-chloro bridging [CuLCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). We herein report the synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties of complex <ce:bold>1.</ce:bold>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: During past decades, the complexes of the type [CuLX2] (L=bidentate ligands containing N atoms, X=Cl or Br) have drawn considerable attention, because of the variable polyhedron for Cu(II) ions and the possibility of magnetic coupling interaction . In these complexes, the center Cu(II) ions can display multifarious geometries: tetrahedron or square-planar (coordination numbers of 4), trigonal bipyramidal or square-pyramidal (coordination numbers of 5) and distorted octahedral (coordination numbers of 6) . The halogen anions play two roles of terminal and bridging ligand. They are situated on axial and/or equatorial position and link the moieties [CuLX2] into dimers or chains. However, up to now, most researches are focus on dimeric Cu(II) complexes . The investigations on the structure and magnetic properties of Chloro-bridged Cu(II) chain complexes are rarely reported . Based on our recent studies , using chiral LRR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine ( ) as bidentate ligand to coordinate to Cu(II) ion, we successfully prepared a 1D chain Cu(II) complex with the single-μ-chloro bridging [CuLCl2] n  (L=LRR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine) (1). We herein report the synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties of complex 1.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was prepared by reaction of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution with <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine in methanol solution, resulting in a green mixture . The mixture was placed undisturbed, and green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained after two weeks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 was prepared by reaction of CuCl2 ⋅2H2O solution with L RR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine in methanol solution, resulting in a green mixture . The mixture was placed undisturbed, and green crystals of 1 were obtained after two weeks.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">X-ray crystal structure analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 reveals that the crystallographic unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of a Cu(II) ion, a chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors and two Cl anions. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, the five-coordinated Cu(II) exhibits distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The bridging Cl1 atom occupies the apical site, while the N1–N2–Cl1A–Cl2 atoms make up the basal plane with mean deviation of 0.2816<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from this plane (symmetric code, A: 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). The Cl1A, Cl2, N1 and N2 atoms deviate from the least-squares plane are 0.2427, −0.2416, −0.3215 and 0.3204<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The central Cu1 lies 0.2407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å away from the least-squares plane, on the other side of the apical atom Cl1. The average Cu1–N bond length is 2.004<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is comparable to the reported complex containing bipy (bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipyridine) . The equatorial Cu1–Cl distances are 2.230 (1) and 2.292 (9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu1–Cl2 and Cu1–Cl1A, respectively, which are shorter than the axial Cu1–Cl1 bond length [2.708(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å]. Cl1 atom bridges between adjacent Cu(II) ions to form the uniform chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cu–Cu distance in the chain is 4.264(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is longer than the similar compound with dichloro-bridging  and single chloro-bridging . In addition, the angle for N1–Cu1–N2 is 79.67°(11) being also close to those of reported compounds [80.5°(3) and 79.6°(3)] . Although introducing chiral ligand to coordinate to Cu(II) ion, we could not obtain the expected chiral 1D chain Cu(II) complex. The reason is that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallize in centrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic> of orthorhombic, which leads to the molecule belonging to mesomer and does not retain chirality.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystal structure analysis of 1  reveals that the crystallographic unit of 1 consists of a Cu(II) ion, a chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors and two Cl anions. As shown in  , the five-coordinated Cu(II) exhibits distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The bridging Cl1 atom occupies the apical site, while the N1-N2-Cl1A-Cl2 atoms make up the basal plane with mean deviation of 0.2816Å from this plane (symmetric code, A: 0.5+ x, y, 0.5- z). The Cl1A, Cl2, N1 and N2 atoms deviate from the least-squares plane are 0.2427, -0.2416, -0.3215 and 0.3204Å, respectively. The central Cu1 lies 0.2407Å away from the least-squares plane, on the other side of the apical atom Cl1. The average Cu1-N bond length is 2.004Å, which is comparable to the reported complex containing bipy (bipy=2,2'-bipyridine) . The equatorial Cu1-Cl distances are 2.230 (1) and 2.292 (9)Å for Cu1-Cl2 and Cu1-Cl1A, respectively, which are shorter than the axial Cu1-Cl1 bond length [2.708(1)Å]. Cl1 atom bridges between adjacent Cu(II) ions to form the uniform chain ( ). The Cu-Cu distance in the chain is 4.264(2)Å, which is longer than the similar compound with dichloro-bridging  and single chloro-bridging . In addition, the angle for N1-Cu1-N2 is 79.67°(11) being also close to those of reported compounds [80.5°(3) and 79.6°(3)] . Although introducing chiral ligand to coordinate to Cu(II) ion, we could not obtain the expected chiral 1D chain Cu(II) complex. The reason is that complex 1 crystallize in centrosymmetric space group Pbca of orthorhombic, which leads to the molecule belonging to mesomer and does not retain chirality.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on SQUID magnetometer based on polycrystalline samples of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> over the temperature range 1.8–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K under the field of 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, above 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> is nearly constant with a value of 0.43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> that is closed to the expected value (0.42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) for isolated <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 Cu(II) ion assuming <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.1. Below 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K this value drastically drops to 0.046<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 1.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Additionally, with the temperature cooling, the susceptibility (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>) increases and reach a maximum of 0.038<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Subsequently, it decreases quickly until 1.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (). All these characteristics indicate that there is a weak intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For further investigations on the magnetic behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the magnetic susceptibility date were analyzed in terms of the polynomial expression  reported by Kahn et al.  for uniform chain of spin <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:display>

elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on SQUID magnetometer based on polycrystalline samples of complex 1 over the temperature range 1.8-300K under the field of 2kOe. As shown in  , above 100K χ m T is nearly constant with a value of 0.43cm3 Kmol-1 that is closed to the expected value (0.42cm3 Kmol-1) for isolated S =1/2 Cu(II) ion assuming g =2.1. Below 100K this value drastically drops to 0.046cm3 Kmol-1 at 1.8K. Additionally, with the temperature cooling, the susceptibility (χ m) increases and reach a maximum of 0.038cm3 mol-1 at 4K. Subsequently, it decreases quickly until 1.8K (). All these characteristics indicate that there is a weak intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling in complex 1. For further investigations on the magnetic behavior of 1, the magnetic susceptibility date were analyzed in terms of the polynomial expression  reported by Kahn et al.  for uniform chain of spin S =1/2  (1)  χ =     Ng   2     β   2     kT     0.25 + 0.074975 x + 0.075235   x   2     1.0 + 0.9931 x + 0.172135   x   2   + 0.757825   x   3       with   x = | J | / kT  .

elements.content:

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−2.276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.16 and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup>

</mml:math>. The negative coupling constant <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> also indicates an intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling between the Cu–Cu ions. As we know, the weak antiferromagnetic coupling is very common in single-chloro and di-chloro bridged Cu(II) complexes with small magnitude of the coupling constant <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The best fit gives the parameters J =-2.276cm-1, g =2.16 and R =5×10-5   [ R = ∑ (   χ   m   obs   -   χ   m   calc     )   2   / ∑ (   χ   m   obs     )   2   ]  . The negative coupling constant J also indicates an intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling between the Cu-Cu ions. As we know, the weak antiferromagnetic coupling is very common in single-chloro and di-chloro bridged Cu(II) complexes with small magnitude of the coupling constant J .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In conclusion, a single-chloro bridging one-dimensional chain Cu(II) complex (CuLCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine), has been synthesized. The investigation on magnetic properties reveal that there is a weak antiferromagnetic coupling interaction between intrachain Cu(II) ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a single-chloro bridging one-dimensional chain Cu(II) complex (CuLCl2)n (L=LRR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine), has been synthesized. The investigation on magnetic properties reveal that there is a weak antiferromagnetic coupling interaction between intrachain Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary data</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CCDC 679943 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.06.007" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.06.007</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized according to the following procedures: a methanol solution (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) containing L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) was added to the methanol solution (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) containing CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) under stirring. The green mixture was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, then filtered and the filtrate left to evaporate at room temperature. The crystals were obtained after two weeks (yield: 51% based on Cu). Elemental analysis (%) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> C<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: Calcd.: C, 53.01; H, 4.68; N, 7.28. Found: C, 52.71; H, 4.92; N, 7.48. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, KBr disc): <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">C</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1506 (s).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 was synthesized according to the following procedures: a methanol solution (10ml) containing LRR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine (0.1mmol, 25mg) was added to the methanol solution (10ml) containing CuCl2 ⋅2H2O (0.1mmol, 17mg) under stirring. The green mixture was stirred for 30min, then filtered and the filtrate left to evaporate at room temperature. The crystals were obtained after two weeks (yield: 51% based on Cu). Elemental analysis (%) for 1 C17H18Cl2CuN2: Calcd.: C, 53.01; H, 4.68; N, 7.28. Found: C, 52.71; H, 4.92; N, 7.48. IR (cm-1, KBr disc): ν C =N=1506 (s).

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para view="all">Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">l2</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>384.77, Orthorhombic, space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.261(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15.855(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>28.785(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3313.7(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å3, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>(0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1576, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.087, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0447, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0825 [<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(I)]. Suitable single crystal of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was mounted on a Brucker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation source (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature using both <ce:italic>Φ</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic>-scan modes. Intensity data were collected in the <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> range of 1.000–26. All absorption corrections were performed with SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with full-matrix least-squares and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculate positions using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-2000 program package. The chiral pinene bipyridine ligand (L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>) in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is disorder with the half-occupancy for C11–C17 and corresponding H atoms.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Crystal data for 1: C17H18Cl2CuN2, M w =384.77, Orthorhombic, space group Pbca, a =7.261(2)Å, b =15.855(4)Å, c =28.785(7)Å, α = β = γ =90°, V =3313.7(2)Å3, Z =8, F(000)=1576, GOF=1.087, R 1 =0.0447, wR 2 =0.0825 [I >2σ(I)]. Suitable single crystal of complex 1 was mounted on a Brucker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation source (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature using both Φ- and ω-scan modes. Intensity data were collected in the θ range of 1.000-26. All absorption corrections were performed with SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculate positions using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-2000 program package. The chiral pinene bipyridine ligand (LRR) in complex 1 is disorder with the half-occupancy for C11-C17 and corresponding H atoms.

The green mixture was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, then filtered and the filtrate left to evaporate at room temperature. The crystals were obtained after two weeks (yield: 51% based on Cu). Elemental analysis (%) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> C<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: Calcd.: C, 53.01; H, 4.68; N, 7.28. Found: C, 52.71; H, 4.92; N, 7.48. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, KBr disc): <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>

The green mixture was stirred for 30min, then filtered and the filtrate left to evaporate at room temperature. The crystals were obtained after two weeks (yield: 51% based on Cu). Elemental analysis (%) for 1 C17H18Cl2CuN2: Calcd.: C, 53.01; H, 4.68; N, 7.28. Found: C, 52.71; H, 4.92; N, 7.48. IR (cm-1, KBr disc): ν C =N=1506 (s).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuL<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was successfully synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a one-dimensional infinite chain polymer, while the magnetic investigations demonstrate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits intrachain Cu(II)–Cu(II) antiferromagnetic interaction with <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−2.276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Using chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf> (−)-4,5 pinene bipyridine, a 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuL<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was synthesized in methanol and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. X-ray analysis shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic> of orthorhombic. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a neutral, one-dimensional infinite chain polymer. The magnetic investigations demonstrate that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits intrachain Cu(II)–Cu(II) antiferromagnetic coupling with <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−2.276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para><ce:para view="all">X-ray crystal structure analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 reveals that the crystallographic unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of a Cu(II) ion, a chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors and two Cl anions. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, the five-coordinated Cu(II) exhibits distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The bridging Cl1 atom occupies the apical site, while the N1–N2–Cl1A–Cl2 atoms make up the basal plane with mean deviation of 0.2816<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from this plane (symmetric code, A: 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). The Cl1A, Cl2, N1 and N2 atoms deviate from the least-squares plane are 0.2427, −0.2416, −0.3215 and 0.3204<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The central Cu1 lies 0.2407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å away from the least-squares plane, on the other side of the apical atom Cl1. The average Cu1–N bond length is 2.004<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is comparable to the reported complex containing bipy (bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipyridine) . The equatorial Cu1–Cl distances are 2.230 (1) and 2.292 (9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu1–Cl2 and Cu1–Cl1A, respectively, which are shorter than the axial Cu1–Cl1 bond length [2.708(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å]. Cl1 atom bridges between adjacent Cu(II) ions to form the uniform chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cu–Cu distance in the chain is 4.264(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is longer than the similar compound with dichloro-bridging  and single chloro-bridging . In addition, the angle for N1–Cu1–N2 is 79.67°(11) being also close to those of reported compounds [80.5°(3) and 79.6°(3)] . Although introducing chiral ligand to coordinate to Cu(II) ion, we could not obtain the expected chiral 1D chain Cu(II) complex. The reason is that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallize in centrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic> of orthorhombic, which leads to the molecule belonging to mesomer and does not retain chirality.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on SQUID magnetometer based on polycrystalline samples of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> over the temperature range 1.8–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K under the field of 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, above 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> is nearly constant with a value of 0.43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> that is closed to the expected value (0.42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) for isolated <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 Cu(II) ion assuming <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.1. Below 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K this value drastically drops to 0.046<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 1.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Additionally, with the temperature cooling, the susceptibility (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>) increases and reach a maximum of 0.038<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Subsequently, it decreases quickly until 1.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (). All these characteristics indicate that there is a weak intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For further investigations on the magnetic behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the magnetic susceptibility date were analyzed in terms of the polynomial expression  reported by Kahn et al.  for uniform chain of spin <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:display>
<ce:formula id="fd1">
<ce:label>(1)</ce:label>
<mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuLRRCl2) n  (LRR =(-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine) (1) was successfully synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. The structure of 1 is a one-dimensional infinite chain polymer, while the magnetic investigations demonstrate that 1 exhibits intrachain Cu(II)-Cu(II) antiferromagnetic interaction with J =-2.276cm-1.

Abstract

Using chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors LRR (-)-4,5 pinene bipyridine, a 1D chain single-μ-chloro bridged Cu(II) complex (CuLRRCl2) n  (1) was synthesized in methanol and characterized by X-ray crystallography and magnetic measurements. X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in space group Pbca of orthorhombic. The structure of 1 is a neutral, one-dimensional infinite chain polymer. The magnetic investigations demonstrate that complex 1 exhibits intrachain Cu(II)-Cu(II) antiferromagnetic coupling with J =-2.276cm-1.

X-ray crystal structure analysis of 1  reveals that the crystallographic unit of 1 consists of a Cu(II) ion, a chiral bidentate ligand containing N-donors and two Cl anions. As shown in  , the five-coordinated Cu(II) exhibits distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The bridging Cl1 atom occupies the apical site, while the N1-N2-Cl1A-Cl2 atoms make up the basal plane with mean deviation of 0.2816Å from this plane (symmetric code, A: 0.5+ x, y, 0.5- z). The Cl1A, Cl2, N1 and N2 atoms deviate from the least-squares plane are 0.2427, -0.2416, -0.3215 and 0.3204Å, respectively. The central Cu1 lies 0.2407Å away from the least-squares plane, on the other side of the apical atom Cl1. The average Cu1-N bond length is 2.004Å, which is comparable to the reported complex containing bipy (bipy=2,2'-bipyridine) . The equatorial Cu1-Cl distances are 2.230 (1) and 2.292 (9)Å for Cu1-Cl2 and Cu1-Cl1A, respectively, which are shorter than the axial Cu1-Cl1 bond length [2.708(1)Å]. Cl1 atom bridges between adjacent Cu(II) ions to form the uniform chain ( ). The Cu-Cu distance in the chain is 4.264(2)Å, which is longer than the similar compound with dichloro-bridging  and single chloro-bridging . In addition, the angle for N1-Cu1-N2 is 79.67°(11) being also close to those of reported compounds [80.5°(3) and 79.6°(3)] . Although introducing chiral ligand to coordinate to Cu(II) ion, we could not obtain the expected chiral 1D chain Cu(II) complex. The reason is that complex 1 crystallize in centrosymmetric space group Pbca of orthorhombic, which leads to the molecule belonging to mesomer and does not retain chirality.

The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on SQUID magnetometer based on polycrystalline samples of complex 1 over the temperature range 1.8-300K under the field of 2kOe. As shown in  , above 100K χ m T is nearly constant with a value of 0.43cm3 Kmol-1 that is closed to the expected value (0.42cm3 Kmol-1) for isolated S =1/2 Cu(II) ion assuming g =2.1. Below 100K this value drastically drops to 0.046cm3 Kmol-1 at 1.8K. Additionally, with the temperature cooling, the susceptibility (χ m) increases and reach a maximum of 0.038cm3 mol-1 at 4K. Subsequently, it decreases quickly until 1.8K (). All these characteristics indicate that there is a weak intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling in complex 1. For further investigations on the magnetic behavior of 1, the magnetic susceptibility date were analyzed in terms of the polynomial expression  reported by Kahn et al.  for uniform chain of spin S =1/2  (1)  χ =     Ng   2     β   2     kT     0.25 + 0.074975 x + 0.075235   x   2     1.0 + 0.9931 x + 0.172135   x   2   + 0.757825   x   3       with   x = | J | / kT  .

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.261(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15.855(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>28.785(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3313.7(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å3, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>(0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1576, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.087, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0447, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0825 [<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(I)]. Suitable single crystal of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was mounted on a Brucker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation source (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature using both <ce:italic>Φ</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic>-scan modes. Intensity data were collected in the <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> range of 1.000–26. All absorption corrections were performed with SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with full-matrix least-squares and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculate positions using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-2000 program package. The chiral pinene bipyridine ligand (L<ce:inf loc="post">RR</ce:inf>) in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is disorder with the half-occupancy for C11–C17 and corresponding H atoms.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Crystal data for 1: C17H18Cl2CuN2, M w =384.77, Orthorhombic, space group Pbca, a =7.261(2)Å, b =15.855(4)Å, c =28.785(7)Å, α = β = γ =90°, V =3313.7(2)Å3, Z =8, F(000)=1576, GOF=1.087, R 1 =0.0447, wR 2 =0.0825 [I >2σ(I)]. Suitable single crystal of complex 1 was mounted on a Brucker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation source (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature using both Φ- and ω-scan modes. Intensity data were collected in the θ range of 1.000-26. All absorption corrections were performed with SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculate positions using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-2000 program package. The chiral pinene bipyridine ligand (LRR) in complex 1 is disorder with the half-occupancy for C11-C17 and corresponding H atoms.
